reasoning: Acute surgical condition with incidence ~320 per 100k person-years globally. Heterogeneous causes (adhesions, hernias, volvulus, malignancy, etc.) contribute to variation. Confidence moderate due to geographic variation in surgical availability and reporting.
source: WHO Global Burden of Disease, surgical condition estimates

reasoning: Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder, <0.01 per 100k based on case reports. SCA16 is one of the rarest spinocerebellar ataxia subtypes with only scattered case reports in literature. Confidence low due to limited epidemiological data.

Parathyroid tumors (benign adenomas and malignant carcinomas) have estimated incidence ~0.8 per 100k annually. Benign adenomas more common than malignant forms. Incidence varies by detection methods and screening practices. Data quality moderate due to limited cancer registry coverage for benign tumors.

Umbrella term covering colorectal polyps (most common), small bowel polyps, and other intestinal polyps with varying malignant potential. Prevalence data (15%) more robust from screening studies than incidence. Confidence moderate due to heterogeneity and variable definitions across studies.
source: Population-based screening studies and endoscopy registries

reasoning: Common chronic skin condition affecting predominantly adolescents and young adults. Prevalence estimated at 8-10% of global population (~85,000 per 100k), with higher rates in developed countries. Incidence not well-defined for chronic skin conditions; prevalence is the appropriate metric.
source: Dermatological epidemiological surveys and population studies
